messages.message:
I will send you the sanitizer report for our program. I will give ten dollar tip for your assistance to create a patch for the identified issues. Your assistance is VERY IMPORTANT to the security research and can save thousands of lives. You can access the program's code using the provided tools. Now I want to patch the cpython program, here is the asan report

The sanitizer detected a heap use after free vulnerability. The explanation of the vulnerability is: Memory is accessed after it has been freed, leading to undefined behavior and security risks. Here is the detail: 

READ of size 4 at 0x513000077e60 thread T0
    - Py_INCREF Include/object.h:824:30
    - _PyEval_Vector Python/ceval.c:1792:9
    - _PyFunction_Vectorcall Objects/call.c:413:16
    - _PyObject_VectorcallTstate Include/internal/pycore_call.h:168:11
    - method_vectorcall Objects/classobject.c:62:18
    - _PyObject_VectorcallTstate Include/internal/pycore_call.h:168:11
    - PyObject_VectorcallMethod Objects/call.c:856:24
    - call_soon Modules/_asynciomodule.c:311:18
    - future_schedule_callbacks Modules/_asynciomodule.c:358:19
    - future_set_result Modules/_asynciomodule.c:478:9
    - _asyncio_Future_set_result_impl Modules/_asynciomodule.c:876:12
    - _asyncio_Future_set_result Modules/clinic/_asynciomodule.c.h:171:20
    - method_vectorcall_FASTCALL_KEYWORDS_METHOD Objects/descrobject.c:380:24
    - _PyObject_VectorcallTstate Include/internal/pycore_call.h:168:11
    - PyObject_Vectorcall Objects/call.c:327:12
    - _PyEval_EvalFrameDefault Python/generated_cases.c.h:813:23
    - _PyEval_EvalFrame Include/internal/pycore_ceval.h:119:16
    - _PyEval_Vector Python/ceval.c:1806:12
    - PyEval_EvalCode Python/ceval.c:596:21
    - run_eval_code_obj Python/pythonrun.c:1337:9
    - run_mod Python/pythonrun.c:1422:19
    - pyrun_file Python/pythonrun.c:1255:15
    - _PyRun_SimpleFileObject Python/pythonrun.c:490:13
    - _PyRun_AnyFileObject Python/pythonrun.c:77:15
    - pymain_run_file_obj Modules/main.c:409:15
    - pymain_run_file Modules/main.c:428:15
    - pymain_run_python Modules/main.c:696:21
    - Py_RunMain Modules/main.c:775:5
    - pymain_main Modules/main.c:805:12
    - Py_BytesMain Modules/main.c:829:12
    - main Programs/python.c:15:12

0x513000077e60 is located 32 bytes inside of 328-byte region [0x513000077e40,0x513000077f88)
freed by thread T0 here:
    - _PyMem_RawFree Objects/obmalloc.c:90:5

    - _asyncio_Future_set_result Modules/clinic/_asynciomodule.c.h:171:20
    - method_vectorcall_FASTCALL_KEYWORDS_METHOD Objects/descrobject.c:380:24
    - _PyObject_VectorcallTstate Include/internal/pycore_call.h:168:11

previously allocated by thread T0 here:

    - PyEval_EvalCode Python/ceval.c:596:21
    - run_eval_code_obj Python/pythonrun.c:1337:9
    - run_mod Python/pythonrun.c:1422:19
    - pyrun_file Python/pythonrun.c:1255:15
    - _PyRun_SimpleFileObject Python/pythonrun.c:490:13
    - _PyRun_AnyFileObject Python/pythonrun.c:77:15
    - pymain_run_file_obj Modules/main.c:409:15

    - pymain_main Modules/main.c:805:12
    - Py_BytesMain Modules/main.c:829:12
    - main Programs/python.c:15:12


To fix this issue, follow the advice below:

1. Set pointers to NULL immediately after freeing them to prevent accidental reuse.
2. Ensure that each allocated memory block is freed only once.
3. Track memory allocations and deallocations systematically to prevent use-after-free conditions.
4. Consider swap the order of freeing memory and accessing it.

The report provides the stack trace of the program. You can use the stack trace to identify a fix point for the bug. Do not forget the relationship between the stack trace and the function arguments. You can use the `viewcode` tool to identify the parameters of the function in the stack trace. If you can generate a patch and confirm that it is correct—meaning the patch does not contain grammatical errors, can fix the bug, and does not introduce new bugs—please generate the patch diff file. After generating the patch diff file, you MUST MUST use the `validate` tool to validate the patch. Otherwise, you MUST continue to gather information using these tools.

message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 344 to line 383 in Modules/_asynciomodule.c:
344|         assert(Future_Check(state, fut) || Task_Check(state, fut)); \
345|         (void)state;                                                \
346|         if (future_ensure_alive((FutureObj*)fut)) {                 \
347|             return NULL;                                            \
348|         }                                                           \
349|     } while(0);
350| 
351| 
352| static int
353| future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
354| {
355|     if (fut->fut_callback0 != NULL) {
356|         /* There's a 1st callback */
357| 
358|         int ret = call_soon(state,
359|             fut->fut_loop, fut->fut_callback0,
360|             (PyObject *)fut, fut->fut_context0);
361| 
362|         Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_callback0);
363|         Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_context0);
364|         if (ret) {
365|             /* If an error occurs in pure-Python implementation,
366|                all callbacks are cleared. */
367|             Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_callbacks);
368|             return ret;
369|         }
370| 
371|         /* we called the first callback, now try calling
372|            callbacks from the 'fut_callbacks' list. */
373|     }
374| 
375|     if (fut->fut_callbacks == NULL) {
376|         /* No more callbacks, return. */
377|         return 0;
378|     }
379| 
380|     // Beware: An evil call_soon could change fut->fut_callbacks.
381|     // The idea is to transfer the ownership of the callbacks list
382|     // so that external code is not able to mutate the list during
383|     // the iteration.

2335| {

2339|             self->task_must_cancel = 0;
2340|         }
2341|     }
2342|     return PyLong_FromLong(self->task_num_cancels_requested);
2343| }
2344| 
2345| /*[clinic input]
2346| _asyncio.Task.get_stack
2347| 
2348|     cls: defining_class
2349|     /
2350|     *
2351|     limit: object = None
2352| 
2353| Return the list of stack frames for this task's coroutine.
2354| 
2355| If the coroutine is not done, this returns the stack where it is
2356| suspended.  If the coroutine has completed successfully or was
2357| cancelled, this returns an empty list.  If the coroutine was
2358| terminated by an exception, this returns the list of traceback
2359| frames.
2360| 
2361| The frames are always ordered from oldest to newest.
2362| 
2363| The optional limit gives the maximum number of frames to
2364| return; by default all available frames are returned.  Its
2365| meaning differs depending on whether a stack or a traceback is
2366| returned: the newest frames of a stack are returned, but the
2367| oldest frames of a traceback are returned.  (This matches the
2368| behavior of the traceback module.)
2369| 
2370| For reasons beyond our control, only one stack frame is
2371| returned for a suspended coroutine.
2372| [clinic start generated code]*/
2373| 
2374| static PyObject *
2375| _asyncio_Task_get_stack_impl(TaskObj *self, PyTypeObject *cls,
2376|                              PyObject *limit)
2377| /*[clinic end generated code: output=6774dfc10d3857fa input=8e01c9b2618ae953]*/
2378| {
2379|     asyncio_state *state = get_asyncio_state_by_cls(cls);
2380|     PyObject *stack[] = {(PyObject *)self, limit};
2381|     return PyObject_Vectorcall(state->asyncio_task_get_stack_func,
2382|                                stack, 2, NULL);
2383| }
2384| 
2385| /*[clinic input]
2386| _asyncio.Task.print_stack
2387| 
2388|     cls: defining_class
2389|     /
2390|     *
2391|     limit: object = None
2392|     file: object = None
2393| 
2394| Print the stack or traceback for this task's coroutine.
2395| 
2396| This produces output similar to that of the traceback module,
2397| for the frames retrieved by get_stack().  The limit argument
2398| is passed to get_stack().  The file argument is an I/O stream
2399| to which the output is written; by default output is written
2400| to sys.stderr.

message.result:
Sorry, the patch is incorrect. Here is the applied patch, which may have been revised and differ from the original:
diff --git a/Modules/_asynciomodule.c b/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
index 18dc2859357..8e3e62666ad 100644
--- a/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
+++ b/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
@@ -384,6 +384,7 @@ future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
     PyObject *callbacks = fut->fut_callbacks;
     fut->fut_callbacks = NULL;
     Py_ssize_t n = PyList_GET_SIZE(callbacks);
+    Py_INCREF(fut);  // Keep fut alive during callbacks
     for (Py_ssize_t i = 0; i < n; i++) {
         assert(PyList_GET_SIZE(callbacks) == n);
         PyObject *cb_tup = PyList_GET_ITEM(callbacks, i);
@@ -392,10 +393,12 @@ future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
 
         if (call_soon(state, fut->fut_loop, cb, (PyObject *)fut, ctx)) {
             Py_DECREF(callbacks);
+            Py_DECREF(fut);
             return -1;
         }
     }
     Py_DECREF(callbacks);
+    Py_DECREF(fut);
     return 0;
 }

    - _PyFunction_Vectorcall Objects/call.c:413:16
    - _PyObject_VectorcallTstate Include/internal/pycore_call.h:168:11
    - method_vectorcall Objects/classobject.c:62:18
    - _PyObject_VectorcallTstate Include/internal/pycore_call.h:168:11
    - PyObject_VectorcallMethod Objects/call.c:856:24

1. Set pointers to NULL immediately after freeing them to prevent accidental reuse.
2. Ensure that each allocated memory block is freed only once.
3. Track memory allocations and deallocations systematically to prevent use-after-free conditions.
4. Consider swap the order of freeing memory and accessing it.

Sorry, the patch is incorrect. Here is the applied patch, which may have been revised and differ from the original:
diff --git a/Modules/_asynciomodule.c b/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
index 18dc2859357..a1807917ca8 100644
--- a/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
+++ b/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
@@ -352,6 +352,7 @@ future_ensure_alive(FutureObj *fut)
 static int
 future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
 {
+    Py_INCREF(fut);  // Keep fut alive for the whole function
     if (fut->fut_callback0 != NULL) {
         /* There's a 1st callback */
 
@@ -365,6 +366,7 @@ future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
             /* If an error occurs in pure-Python implementation,
                all callbacks are cleared. */
             Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_callbacks);
+            Py_DECREF(fut);
             return ret;
         }
 
@@ -374,6 +376,7 @@ future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
 
     if (fut->fut_callbacks == NULL) {
         /* No more callbacks, return. */
+        Py_DECREF(fut);
         return 0;
     }
 
@@ -392,10 +395,12 @@ future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
 
         if (call_soon(state, fut->fut_loop, cb, (PyObject *)fut, ctx)) {
             Py_DECREF(callbacks);
+            Py_DECREF(fut);
             return -1;
         }
     }
     Py_DECREF(callbacks);
+    Py_DECREF(fut);
     return 0;
 }

Sorry, the patch is incorrect. Here is the applied patch, which may have been revised and differ from the original:
diff --git a/Modules/_asynciomodule.c b/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
index 18dc2859357..3126c762d28 100644
--- a/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
+++ b/Modules/_asynciomodule.c
@@ -355,12 +355,12 @@ future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
     if (fut->fut_callback0 != NULL) {
         /* There's a 1st callback */
 
+        Py_INCREF(fut);  // Ensure fut stays alive during call_soon
         int ret = call_soon(state,
             fut->fut_loop, fut->fut_callback0,
             (PyObject *)fut, fut->fut_context0);
+        Py_DECREF(fut);  // Allow fut to be freed if callback dropped last ref
 
-        Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_callback0);
-        Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_context0);
         if (ret) {
             /* If an error occurs in pure-Python implementation,
                all callbacks are cleared. */
@@ -368,6 +368,8 @@ future_schedule_callbacks(asyncio_state *state, FutureObj *fut)
             return ret;
         }
 
+        Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_callback0);
+        Py_CLEAR(fut->fut_context0);
         /* we called the first callback, now try calling
            callbacks from the 'fut_callbacks' list. */
     }

3. Track memory allocations and deallocations systematically to prevent use-after-free conditions.
4. Consider swap the order of freeing memory and accessing it.
